### Medioid Approach
Computer 1: Wasserstein, p=1, then run similarity on mahattan
Computer 2: Wasserstein, p=1, then run similarity on euclidean
Computer 3: Bottleneck, then run similairty on manhattan
Computer 4: Bottleneck, then run similarity on euclidean

```{r}
n <- 100
collection <- book_list

#Computer 1
similarity_table <- clustering_PD_wasserstein(n, collection)
pamx <- pam(similarity_table, 5, diss = FALSE, cluster.only = FALSE, metric = "manhattan")

#Computer 2
similarity_table <- clustering_PD_wasserstein(n, collection)
pamx <- pam(similarity_table, 5, diss = FALSE, cluster.only = FALSE, metric = "euclidean")

#Computer 3
similarity_table <- clustering_PD_bottleneck(n, collection)
pamx <- pam(similarity_table, 5, diss = FALSE, cluster.only = FALSE, metric = "manhattan")

#Computer 4
similarity_table <- clustering_PD_bottleneck(n, collection)
pamx <- pam(similarity_table, 5, diss = FALSE, cluster.only = FALSE, metric = "euclidean")


return_scores(pamx)
```
